questions.text: Which of the following groups of axillary lymph nodes are considered level I nodes in breast lymphatic drainage?
questions.solution:
Lymphatic Drainage of the Breast

  • Axillary lymph nodes: Major route of lymphatic drainage for the breast (85%).
    • Level I: Lateral nodes, below and lateral to the lateral border of the pectoralis minor.
    • Level II: Located behind and around the pectoralis minor, including Rotter's nodes.
    • Level III: Apical nodes, above and medial to the pectoralis minor.
  • Internal mammary nodes: Drain the medial half of the breast and lie along the internal mammary vessels, deep to the costal cartilages.

Option A) Incorrect. Central nodes are located in the center of the axilla, embedded in fat, and are classified as level II nodes.

Option B) Correct. Lateral nodes are found along the lower border of the axillary vein and are classified as level I nodes, lying lateral to the thoracodorsal vascular pedicle.

Option C) Incorrect. Apical nodes are classified as level III, located above and medial to the pectoralis minor muscle.

Option D) Incorrect. Rotter's nodes, lying between the pectoralis major and minor muscles, are classified under level II.

Key Points:

Axillary lymph nodes are divided into three levels based on their location relative to the pectoralis minor muscle. The lateral group (Level I) is the most common site of breast lymphatic drainage.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents with a palpable breast lump. She reports no pain or other symptoms. A mammogram reveals dense breast tissue and an ultrasound is performed, revealing a well-circumscribed, mobile, solid mass. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Breast Imaging

  • Ultrasonography: Primary imaging modality in young women with dense breasts, especially when mammograms are difficult to interpret. It can differentiate between cystic and solid lesions.
    • Fibroadenoma: Well-circumscribed, mobile, solid mass seen on ultrasound, typically in young women, with an extremely low likelihood of malignancy. Management involves reassurance and follow-up imaging.
    • Simple Cysts: Do not require further work-up unless symptomatic. Therapeutic aspiration can be done for painful cysts.
  • Malignant Features on Imaging: Irregular-shaped, solid masses with ill-defined margins (spiculated, angular) on ultrasonography require biopsy, as they are suspicious for malignancy.
  • Mammography: First-line imaging in older women or women with breast symptoms. It is also used as an initial screening tool in asymptomatic women as part of population-based programs.
  • MRI: Used in dense breasts or equivocal mammogram/ultrasound findings, and in high-risk women (e.g., BRCA mutations, strong family history).

Option A) Incorrect. A biopsy is not indicated for a well-circumscribed, mobile mass in a young woman, which is suggestive of fibroadenoma.

Option B) Correct. A well-circumscribed, mobile, solid mass in a young woman is highly suggestive of a fibroadenoma, which has a very low likelihood of malignancy. The appropriate management is reassurance and imaging follow-up.

Option C) Incorrect. Mastectomy is an invasive treatment and not appropriate for a likely benign lesion such as a fibroadenoma.

Option D) Incorrect. Radiation therapy is used in the treatment of malignancies, not for benign lesions like fibroadenomas

Key Points:

  • Ultrasonography: Key in distinguishing cystic from solid lesions. Mammography: Important in older women for screening and diagnosis.

choices.text: No further action required if asymptomatic

questions.text: A 55-year-old female undergoes a mammogram as part of her routine screening. The report indicates a BI-RADS 4b category lesion. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A) Routine annual screening - Incorrect. BI-RADS 4 lesions suggest suspicion for malignancy, and follow-up with just annual screening would not be appropriate.

Option B) Biopsy - Correct. BI-RADS 4 lesions indicate a moderate to high suspicion of malignancy, particularly 4b (10-50% malignancy risk), necessitating biopsy to confirm the diagnosis.

Option C) Follow-up imaging in 6 months - Incorrect. This option is appropriate for BI-RADS 3, which indicates "probably benign" findings.

Option D) No further action required if asymptomatic - Incorrect. Action must be taken based on radiological findings, not just the presence or absence of symptoms.

Key Points:

  • BI-RADS 3: Short-term follow-up.
  • BI-RADS 4-6: Requires biopsy for definitive diagnosis.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with cyclical mastalgia that has been worsening over the past few months, especially just before her periods. She has no palpable lumps on breast examination and her imaging studies are normal. What is the first-line treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
Mastalgia

  • Cyclical Mastalgia:
    • Pain related to the menstrual cycle, generally starting mid-cycle and increasing in severity until menstruation. Both breasts are usually involved.
    • Hormonal sensitivity, possibly due to estrogen.
  • Non-Cyclical Mastalgia:
    • Unrelated to the menstrual cycle, localized to a specific region of the breast. Causes include duct ectasia, trauma, and musculoskeletal pain.
    • Causes: Trauma, infections, musculoskeletal causes (e.g., Tietze's syndrome), and occasionally malignancy
  • Management:
    • First-line: Reassurance, lifestyle modifications, supportive bras, and reducing caffeine intake.
    • Medical Treatment: Tamoxifen 10 mg or Danazol 50-300 mg for severe cases.
    • Topical NSAIDs: For localized breast pain, topical diclofenac or piroxicam may be used.

Option A) Oral contraceptives - Incorrect. Oral contraceptives are not the first-line treatment for mastalgia, particularly cyclical mastalgia.

Option B) Tamoxifen 10 mg daily - Incorrect. Tamoxifen is used for severe cases of mastalgia but not as the first-line treatment.

Option C) Reassurance and lifestyle modification - Correct. Most cases of cyclical mastalgia are benign, and reassurance along with lifestyle changes such as reducing caffeine and using supportive bras is recommended.

Option D) Immediate biopsy - Incorrect. Mastalgia without concerning features on examination or imaging does not require a biopsy.

Key Points:

  • Cyclical mastalgia responds well to reassurance and lifestyle modifications. Severe cases may require treatment with tamoxifen or danazol.

choices.text: Wide local excision with a 2 cm margin

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with a large, rapidly growing breast mass that has an uneven surface. The overlying skin is intact, and the mass remains mobile on the chest wall. Biopsy reveals both epithelial and mesenchymal elements. What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Phyllodes Tumour

  • Also Known As: Previously called cystosarcoma phyllodes.
  • Age Group: Commonly occurs in women over the age of 30, though it can appear in younger women.
  • Characteristics: Large, unevenly bosselated, mobile tumor that rarely infiltrates the skin early.
  • Histology: True mixed neoplasm with both epithelial and mesenchymal elements.
  • Classification: Based on histological behavior:
    • Benign: Mitotic rate <4 per 10 HPF.
    • Borderline: Mitotic rate 4-9 per 10 HPF.
    • Malignant: Mitotic rate >10 per 10 HPF.

Treatment:

  • Primary: Wide local excision with a 2 cm margin, including overlying skin and underlying pectoralis major muscle.
  • Mastectomy: For massive or recurrent tumours.
  • Post-op Radiotherapy: Considered for recurrent or malignant phyllodes tumours.
  • Chemotherapy: For malignant phyllodes tumours in some cases.

Option A): Incorrect. Fine needle aspiration can diagnose the mass but is not the definitive treatment.

Option B) Correct. Wide local excision with a 2 cm margin is the standard treatment for phyllodes tumor to prevent local recurrence.

Option C): Incorrect. Hormonal therapy is not effective in the treatment of phyllodes tumours.

Option D): Incorrect. Mastectomy is reserved for massive tumours, recurrent tumours, or malignant phyllodes

Key Points:

Phyllodes tumors have low metastatic potential but a high risk of local recurrence.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman presents with a 2 cm, well-circumscribed, mobile breast lump. Ultrasound confirms a typical fibroadenoma. What is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
Fibroadenoma

  • Most Common Cause: The most common cause of a breast lump in women aged 15-25 years.
  • Origin: Hyperplasia of a lobule, typically 2-3 cm in size, surrounded by a well-defined capsule.
  • Management:
  • Observation: For clinically typical fibroadenomas confirmed on ultrasound.
  • Biopsy: Indicated if the patient is over 25 or if there are atypical features on ultrasound.
  • Indications for Surgical Excision:
    • Age over 30 years.
    • Suspicious features on imaging (micro lobulation, atypia on histology).
    • Size >5 cm (giant fibroadenoma).
    • Family history of breast cancer.
  • Risk of Cancer: The relative risk of cancer with simple fibroadenoma is 1.5-1.7, and 3.0-4.0 in the presence of complex fibroadenoma and a family history of breast cancer.

Option A) Correct. Clinically typical fibroadenomas in women under 25 can be observed without biopsy.

Option B) Incorrect. Fine needle aspiration can be used to confirm diagnosis, but observation is preferred if there are no atypical features.

Option C) Incorrect. Surgical excision is reserved for fibroadenomas larger than 5 cm or with suspicious features.

Option D) Incorrect. Chemotherapy is not indicated for fibroadenomas

Key Points:

Observation is the standard for simple, small fibroadenomas. Surgical excision is needed for larger fibroadenomas or those with suspicious features.

choices.text: Wide excision of the nipple and areola, including underlying ducts, followed by radiotherapy
Mastectomy with axillary lymph node dissection
No further action if there is no associated malignancy

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents with eczematous changes to the nipple that have not responded to topical steroids. There is associated destruction of the nipple and encroachment onto the areola. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Paget's Disease of the Nipple

  • A rare type of ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) presenting in the nipple and areola.
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Erosion of the nipple with slow destruction, usually without an underlying mass. Often mistaken for eczema.
  • Pathophysiology: Paget's cells migrate through the ducts into the skin of the nipple.
  • Diagnosis: Wedge biopsy confirms the diagnosis.
  • Treatment:
    • Without underlying malignancy: Central core excision (removal of major milk ducts, nipple, and areola) followed by radiotherapy.
    • with underlying malignancy: Mastectomy and axillary node evaluation.

Option A) Incorrect. Persistent eczematous changes that do not respond to steroids.

Option B) Incorrect. Wide excision alone may be insufficient.

Option C) Correct. Paget's disease of the breast is often associated with an underlying ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) or invasive carcinoma. The standard treatment is mastectomy with axillary lymph node dissection, especially when there is evidence of an underlying malignancy.

Option D) Incorrect. as it is often associated with breast cancer

Key Points:

Associated with DCIS, but may progress to invasive carcinoma.

Triple assessment (clinical exam, imaging, biopsy) is mandatory to exclude underlying malignancy.

choices.text: Continue breastfeeding and treat with oral antibiotics
Stop breastfeeding and drain the abscess via incision and drainage
Continue breastfeeding and perform ultrasound-guided aspiration of the abscess
Stop breastfeeding and treat with oral antibiotics

questions.text: A 30-year-old breastfeeding mother presents with a painful, swollen right breast. She has fever, malaise, and difficulty breastfeeding. On examination, there is erythema and tenderness of the breast with a fluctuant lump. An ultrasound reveals a collection of pus. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Lactational Mastitis

  • Inflammation of the breast during lactation, most commonly caused by Staphylococcus aureus.
  • Risk Factors: Improper breastfeeding technique, cracked nipples, blocked ducts.
  • Clinical Presentation: Pain, erythema, fever, and fluctuant lump due to abscess formation.
  • Ultrasound: Key for identifying abscesses, which appear as hypoechoic collections with floating debris.
  • Management:
    • Cellulitic stage: Anti-staphylococcal antibiotics (e.g., cloxacillin), breastfeeding encouragement, breast support, cold compresses.
    • Abscess stage: Ultrasound-guided aspiration of pus for culture and sensitivity, continued breastfeeding, and antibiotics for 14 days. Incision and drainage may result in complications like milk fistulae, hence ultrasound-guided aspiration is preferred.

Option A) Incorrect. Abscesses require drainage in addition to antibiotics.

Option B) Incorrect. Stopping breastfeeding is not necessary. The current recommendation is to continue breastfeeding, as it helps with drainage and prevents milk stasis.

Option C) Correct. Ultrasound-guided aspiration is a minimally invasive method to drain the abscess and is the preferred initial approach. The patient should also continue breastfeeding.

Option D) Incorrect. Breastfeeding is not stopped in lactational mastitis.

Key Points:

Ultrasound-guided aspiration is the preferred approach for abscesses, allowing continued breastfeeding and reducing the risk of milk fistulae.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female smoker presents with central breast pain and purulent discharge from the nipple. She has a firm, tender subareolar lump with retraction of the nipple. Ultrasound shows thickened major milk ducts with surrounding inflammation. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Non-Lactational Mastitis (Periductal Mastitis)

  • Chronic inflammation around the major milk ducts, often autoimmune in nature.
  • Risk Factors: More common in smokers, nulliparous women, or long after cessation of lactation.
  • Clinical Presentation: Central non-cyclical breast pain, nipple discharge (purulent), subareolar abscess, and nipple retraction ("fish mouth" appearance). Can mimic carcinoma.
  • Diagnosis: Ultrasound shows thickened milk ducts with inflammation or abscess. Pus should be cultured, and TB should be ruled out.
  • Management: Antibiotics (anti-staphylococcal), needle aspiration for abscesses. Surgical excision of major ducts may be required for recurrent cases or if a fistula develops.

Explanation of Options:

Option A) Periductal mastitis: Correct answer. This condition commonly occurs in smokers and is associated with inflammation of the major breast ducts.

Option B) Idiopathic granulomatous mastitis: Incorrect. This is a rare, chronic inflammatory condition of the breast, typically presenting as a firm, painless mass, and not associated with purulent discharge or smoking.

Option C) Tubercular mastitis: Incorrect. Tubercular mastitis is uncommon, often presents with chronic, painless breast lumps, and is usually associated with systemic symptoms like fever, night sweats, and weight loss.

Option D) Ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS): Incorrect. DCIS is a non-invasive breast cancer that typically presents as microcalcifications on a mammogram.

Key Points:

Smoking cessation is important in managing periductal mastitis.Chronic periductal mastitis can mimic malignancy and must be distinguished from cancer.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with a tender, cord-like structure beneath the skin of the right breast, which is attached to the skin. When she raises her arm, a shallow groove becomes visible. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Mondor's Disease

  • Thrombophlebitis of the superficial veins of the breast and anterior chest wall.
  • Clinical Features: Tender, thrombosed subcutaneous cord attached to the skin. The groove is visible when the arm is raised.
  • Differential Diagnosis: Lymphatic permeation from an occult carcinoma of the breast.
  • Management: Restriction of arm movements. The condition typically subsides within a few months without recurrence or complications.

Explanation of options:

Option A) Incorrect. Breast cancer can cause skin changes but usually presents with a mass or nipple discharge rather than a cord-like structure.

Option B) Incorrect. Superficial thrombophlebitis involves the superficial veins, but the clinical presentation of Mondor's disease, including the visible groove, is more specific.

Option C) Correct. Mondor's disease is characterized by a thrombosed subcutaneous vein, usually attached to the skin, with a visible groove when the skin is stretched.

Option D) Incorrect. Mastitis typically presents with inflammation, fever, and sometimes abscess formation, not a cord-like structure.

Key Points:

Pathognomonic feature is a tender thrombosed cord under the skin. Mondor's disease typically resolves without complications or deformity.

questions.text: A 16-year-old female presents with the absence of the left breast. She is otherwise healthy but has short webbed fingers on her left hand. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Amazia and Poland's Syndrome

  • Amazia: Congenital absence of the breast, which can be unilateral or bilateral.
  • Poland's Syndrome:
    • Congenital condition characterised by the absence of the sternal portion of the pectoralis major and the breast on the same side.
    • Associated with limb abnormalities, including short webbed fingers (symbrachydactyly).
    • Management: Breast reconstruction with a latissimus dorsi muscle flap and silicone implant is often considered.

Explanation of Options:

Option A) Correct. Poland's syndrome is characterized by the absence of the breast (amazia) and the sternal portion of the pectoralis major muscle, often accompanied by limb abnormalities such as symbrachydactyly.

Option B) Incorrect. Turner syndrome presents with features like short stature and webbed neck, not amazia.

Option C) Incorrect. Amazia refers to the absence of the breast, but Poland's syndrome includes additional features such as limb abnormalities.

Option D) Incorrect. Gynecomastia refers to the enlargement of male breast tissue and is not related to congenital absence of the breast.

Key Points:

Amazia is the absence of the breast, sometimes associated with Poland's syndrome.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female undergoes a mastectomy for breast cancer and is scheduled for breast reconstruction using a transverse rectus abdominis muscle (TRAM) flap. She has a history of smoking and previous abdominal liposuction. The surgeon discusses her candidacy for this type of reconstruction. Which of the following factors in her history is an absolute contraindication for TRAM flap reconstruction?
questions.solution:
TRAM Flap Reconstruction

  • Indications:
    • Suitable for breast reconstruction in patients with small to large breasts and in cases of breast ptosis.
  • Relative Contraindications:
    • Include smoking, previous abdominal liposuction, obesity, and pulmonary disease.
  • Absolute Contraindications:
    • Include prior abdominoplasty and inability to tolerate the longer procedure and recovery time.
  • Advantages:
    • Autologous tissue reconstruction allows the breast to change proportionally with the body during weight changes and can improve the contour of donor sites.
  • Disadvantages:
    • TRAM flap surgery has a longer operative time, involves multiple surgical sites, and has the potential for flap loss.

Option A) Smoking: This is a relative contraindication, but not an absolute one. Smoking increases the risk of flap necrosis and wound healing complications but doesn't necessarily preclude the surgery.

Option B) Previous abdominal liposuction: Correct. Previous liposuction can compromise the blood supply to the abdominal tissues, making it a relative contraindication for using the TRAM flap.

Option C) Previous abdominoplasty: Correct. This is an absolute contraindication because prior surgery can significantly alter the abdominal musculature and blood supply.

Option D) Obesity: This is a relative contraindication, but it is not as significant as prior abdominal surgery.

Key Points:

TRAM flap reconstruction is often indicated when there is a history of radiation or infection. Prior abdominal surgery (e.g., abdominoplasty) is a contraindication due to potential compromised blood supply.

choices.text: Nipple retraction due to breast cancer, requiring biopsy.
Nipple inversion, typically congenital, with no association with cancer.
Nipple retraction secondary to periductal mastitis, requiring antibiotics.
Nipple inversion requiring immediate surgical correction due to risk of infection.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman presents to the clinic with complaints of an inverted left nipple. She has noticed it since adolescence and reports no associated pain, discharge, or mass. Upon examination, there is no associated skin thickening or palpable lump. The nipple remains inverted when manually manipulated.

What is the most likely diagnosis and management for this condition?
questions.solution:
Nipple Inversion and Retraction

  • Nipple Inversion: A congenital condition due to the failure of elongation of major milk ducts, common and benign. It does not predispose to breast cancer.
  • Nipple Retraction: An acquired condition due to fibrosis, often related to periductal mastitis or breast cancer. Sudden retraction with other suspicious features may indicate malignancy.
  • Management of Nipple Retraction: New onset retraction warrants further evaluation (e.g., mammography, biopsy) to rule out carcinoma. Longstanding retraction is often due to periductal mastitis and treated with antibiotics if infected.
  • Cracked Nipple: Common in lactating women, requiring rest, proper hygiene, and topical antimicrobials to prevent mastitis.

Explanation of Options:

Option A) Incorrect. Nipple retraction due to breast cancer is characterized by recent onset, often accompanied by a palpable mass or other suspicious features like skin thickening.

Option B) Correct. Nipple inversion is usually congenital, benign, and not associated with an increased risk of breast cancer. It can cause issues with breastfeeding but does not typically require intervention unless it becomes infected.

Option C) Incorrect. Periductal mastitis can cause nipple retraction with an inflamed, slit-like appearance, but this patient has no signs of infection or pain, making this diagnosis less likely.

Option D) Incorrect. Surgical correction is not immediately necessary for congenital nipple inversion unless recurrent infections occur or there are significant breastfeeding issues.

Key Points:

Nipple Inversion: Congenital and benign, not associated with cancer.

Nipple Retraction: Acquired and concerning for malignancy if recent onset.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presents with a spontaneous, single-duct, serous nipple discharge. The discharge is non-tender, and she denies any palpable lumps or other systemic symptoms. Triple assessment, including ultrasonography, is performed. What is the most likely cause of this discharge?
questions.solution:
Nipple Discharge

  • Pathological Discharge:
    • Defined by the 'Four S' - Single duct, Serous/Sanguineous, Spontaneous.
    • These discharges should always undergo triple assessment (clinical exam, imaging, and biopsy).
  • Common Causes:
  • Serous: Ductal papilloma, usually a benign lesion but requires assessment.
  • Sanguineous: Could be due to papilloma, ductal carcinoma, or ductal ectasia.
  • Multiduct Multicoloured Discharge: Generally physiological and seen in benign conditions like duct ectasia.
  • Galactorrhoea: Associated with elevated prolactin levels due to prolactinoma or medication side effects.
  • During Pregnancy: A bloody discharge is often physiological but needs ultrasonography to rule out malignancy.

Explanation of Options:

Option A) Incorrect. Duct ectasia typically presents with a multiduct, multicolored (green, black, or muddy) discharge.

Option B) Incorrect. Prolactinoma causes galactorrhoea, which is spontaneous milk discharge from both nipples.

Option C) Correct. A single-duct, serous discharge is most commonly associated with a ductal papilloma. It is potentially serious and needs evaluation with triple assessment.

Option D) Incorrect. Breast carcinoma may present with sanguineous discharge or palpable masses, but serous discharge is more likely due to benign lesions like papillomas.

Key Points:

Serous discharge: Typically caused by ductal papilloma and requires evaluation. Triple assessment: Essential for pathological discharges (Four S criteria).

questions.text: A 17-year-old male presents with a lump under his left nipple that has been gradually increasing in size for the last 6 months. The patient is otherwise healthy with no significant medical history. On examination, there is a 3 cm soft, non-tender mass beneath the left nipple, with no signs of discharge. What is the most likely underlying cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
Gynecomastia

  • Gynecomastia refers to benign enlargement of male breast tissue due to an imbalance between estrogens and androgens.

Physiologic Phases:

  • Neonatal: Due to maternal estrogens.
  • Adolescent: Occurs between ages 12-15 due to an increase in estradiol relative to testosterone.
  • Senescence: In older males due to a fall in testosterone levels leading to relative hyperestrinism.

Pathophysiology: Excess estrogen (e.g., from gonadal or non-gonadal sources), decreased testosterone, or pharmacologic agents (e.g., digitalis, spironolactone) can result in gynecomastia.

Clinical Grading:

  • Grade I: Mild enlargement without skin redundancy.
  • Grade IIa: Moderate enlargement without skin redundancy.
  • Grade IIb: Moderate enlargement with skin redundancy.
  • Grade III: Marked enlargement with skin redundancy and ptosis.

Associated Conditions:

  • Klinefelter's syndrome (XXY): Hypoandrogenic state leading to gynecomastia.
  • Endocrine Disorders: Hyperthyroidism, hypothyroidism, cirrhosis.
  • Tumours: Testicular germ cell tumors, adrenal tumors, hepatocellular carcinoma.

Explanation of Options:

Option A) Klinefelter's syndrome: Klinefelter's syndrome (XXY) is a genetic disorder associated with hypoandrogenism and gynecomastia, but it is more common in adulthood rather than in adolescence.

Option B) Physiologic gynecomastia: Correct. During puberty, a temporary imbalance between estrogens and testosterone leads to gynecomastia in adolescent males. It is a common benign condition.

Option C) Breast carcinoma: While breast cancer can occur in males, especially older individuals or those with a family history, this patient's presentation is more consistent with physiologic gynecomastia.

Option D) Sertoli cell tumor: A rare testicular tumor that can produce estrogens and lead to gynecomastia, but this is not the most common cause in a healthy adolescent.

Key Points:

Physiologic gynecomastia is common in adolescents and resolves spontaneously. Grading helps determine the severity and need for surgical intervention.
